posts.name: jlawhead
posts.cooked:
The commands used in our Java command-based auto are here:

The issue we are having is our command, “shootCenterNotes” is not running the intake to grab a second note only in live matches. It works great on the bench in our pit and on the practice field.

We use a command composition to shoot a pre-loaded note, roll back a specified distance while also running the intake until the sensor detects a note, then roll forward and shoot again. If the intake doesn’t find a note, it should just keep running and the robot should sit there. We originally had it timeout, so we could build on this for a three-note auto but removed that so we could troubleshoot.

We thought the only differences from our successful test environmenta were the field lighting and the FMS . We’ve triple-checked the photoreflective sensor and shielded it from ambient lighting. Now I’m thinking the intake is being locked by the shooting command that also uses the intake to feed the note, but it’s on a 2.5 second deadline. I don’t understand why we’d only see a conflict in a live match.

Any ideas?

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: Is it possible that your photo eye is being confused by the field lighting and deciding you have a note loaded?  Consider putting a shroud on it, maybe some black tape.  Also consider debouncing it.

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
I am still confused with what it actually does in the failure scenario. Does it lower the intake?  Then it backs up with the intake off?  Does it continue after that or just sit there?

Can you add debugging by either putting a printcommand on the end condition of the intake fast or by constantly plotting the value of the sensor to NT the entire time (this may be more helpful).

posts.name: jlawhead
posts.cooked: Yes definitely possible. We put a soft black shroud over the top and the robot that didn’t trigger the photo eye in testing and also print the value and the Boolean to the dashboard and there’s no evidence it’s being triggered.

posts.name: jlawhead
posts.cooked: The failure scenario at this point is just to have the robot sit there having backed out with the intake running so we can see if the intake will start. It runs fine for the shooting command just before that maneuver and is halted by a 2.5 sec. timer. Another possibility is there’s over lap between the shooting timer which uses the intake and the start of the intake, but we have a .5 sec delay while our arm lowers and there’s no conflict when testing off the field.

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked: I didn’t understand your answer.  You didn’t seem to answer any of my questions. I am trying to understand exactly what it does onfield. Also what you expect it to do is the 2.5 seconds is expected according to your code

posts.name: jlawhead
posts.cooked:
Ah ok sorry.

The robot is based on the Ri3D Quokka bot. The intake rollers can pick up a note and also feed it to the larger shooter rollers. To shoot a note, the shooter rollers spin up first for .5 seconds and then the intake starts.  We then run the rollers for 2.5 seconds which is more than enough time for the note to leave. After 2.5 seconds, the shooting sequence ends so the intake is available again for the next action.

All of our discrete actions are set up as methods that are command factories which we then use to builds command compositions.

When Autonomous starts:

The robot shoots a pre-loaded note for 2.5 seconds. We then lower the arm from the shooting angle to the floor angle using states and a PID controller. We wait .5 seconds for that to happen and then start the intake which runs until it has a note. The robot drives backwards for the distance where it should hit the note and hopefully it grabs it. If it grabs and the sensor detects it, the robot rolls forward to the speaker while raising the arm, and then shoots the second note. If it fails to grab the note form the floor, the robot just sits there with the intake running until autonomous ends.

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
I am trying to figure out which of the auto steps happen when you run it (I assume it has issues?) on the real field?  It sounds like the intake doesn’t turn on.  There are two possibilities I see as likely, it turned on and then off very quickly, or it never turned on.  So I am trying to diagnose exactly what steps it did and did not complete when it “failed” on the real field.  Did it lower the intake?  Did it move forwards again?

You mentioned that you added printing the boolean value.  This true false would happen very fast and if you were just printing you many not have caught it.  That is why if you went that method I was suggesting you log it to NT so you could check the datalog.  If you want to go the “print” route I would do something like this: return Commands.print("######## intake started #######").andThen(s_Intake.fast().until(s_Intake::hasNote)).andThen(Commands.print("#### intake stopped ####"));
